I'm a big fan of the Splinter Cell games that came before this one. This one was honestly a bit lackluster compared to the rest of the series. It seemed like this game wasn't even about stealth. Then again, it could have been just how I played, but compared to the rest of the Splinter Cell series this seemed to lose all sense of stealth that I loved about this series. The weapon stash feature was unnecessary in my opinion. I don't know why Ubisoft tries to add weapon customization in their games, but it didn't work very well with this game. It only took about two missions to get full upgrades on the one pistol that I used throughout the entire game. I think I only used the automatic weapons for about 10 minutes throughout the whole game. Just seemed like a pointless feature to me.

Pros:
- Graphics are beautiful, I took screens of the ones that I liked most.
- Interesting-ish story.
- Interrogation methods are cool
- Killing guys through windows
- Explosions
- Execution mode was interesting, although it would have worked better if it required the player to be more active in it, rather than just marking targets, pressing 'e', and letting it happen.

Cons:
- Controls are wonky as ♥♥♥♥
- Lack of quicksave ability
- Lack of stealthy missions; The reason why I like the Splinter Cell games (in addition to the story) is because of how stealthy you can be. But this game it seemed like you just threw out a frag from behind cover, then once it blew up you would just shoot as many guys as you could. I wanted to go around in the shadows and grab guys, not just get headshots and move on.
- Length; Only about 6 hours of gameplay in the solo campaign compared to Splinter Cell 1 and Chaos Theory which had 10-12 hours.
- Weapon stash

Overall the cons outweigh the pros with this game. However, if you're a Splinter Cell fan, you should still play this game just to say you played the whole series. Not worth it if you're just playing casually though... unless you like pretty graphics and explosions.

reviewText:
Splinter Cell: Conviction is a good game for gamers that enjoy shooters, military, and a rich-linear campaign. Conviction is about Sam Fisher, an agent that has gone rogue following his work at the Third Echelon. He is on the hunt to find his daughter following a new Third Echelon leader chasing after Fisher to kill him. I have not played any main Splinter Cell games prior to this so I am not sure if it expands on the story. To note, I have not played the Deniable Ops mode, a mode that is using strategy to fend off numerous enemies, and I have not played multiplayer or co-op.

Campaign: Conviction has a good campaign. The campaign clocked in at 6.4 hours on 'normal' difficulty. The story is rich in that there are many twists and turns in the campaign and a wide-variety of settings for the player to play. For example, we get a solid background of Fisher moving on from Third Echelon, to Third Echelon wanting him dead by using his daughter, to then utilising Third Echelon to reveal their overall goal in a great twist in the story.

The campaign is linear meaning you have to do that particular task, but still works well within the story of the game. The cut scenes are very nice and they flow well. However, I would have liked to see more variety in Fisher's gameplay. For example, when he is angry compared to his normal mood as it was the same despite his emotions.

I feel the campaign could have been at least one-two hours longer.

Gameplay: Average gameplay. The gameplay was fluid and solid. The reasoning's is that things such as the execute ability and the gameplay from interrogation elements to using the environment were good.  It was really the little things in the gameplay that made me enjoy it as much as I did including the interrogation, or the cover system in relation to enemy movement, etc.

However, there were numerous negatives with the gameplay stemming from the camera movement on Fisher when in cover and attempting to shoot enemies, to trying to shoot enemies and the inability to zoom in. In other words, certain elements of gameplay including the cover system felt entirely disjointed and took away a heap from the overall gameplay.

To get further longetivity out of the game, I think having slower gameplay that is more fluid would have made the game better, by producing more variety in movement. For example, making the transition from cover to cover slower to capture the feeling of needing to hurry and switch covers.

Graphics and Dialogue: The graphics were surprisingly very good for a game released in 2011. To note, I played the game on Medium graphics out of the three options of low, medium, and high and the graphics were very nice. I felt this game wasn't overly optimised as my PC has specs much better than the recommended specs for this game but I could not achieve a constant and stable 60FPS, even I couldn't achieve a stable 30FPS, including no option to lock the game to 30FPS.

The dialogue is strong in Conviction. There is a heap of variety in each character's dialogue that truly captures all individual characters personality.

Expansion: For $19.99, I would not recommend the Insurgency pack at all. If you are not going to play the Deniable Ops mode as that can get very boring without friends to play with, then there is no reason to purchase the Insurgency pack. If you have friends that regularly play games with you, purchase the Insurgency pack to get many hours more out of the game.

Overall: The positives were there, but the main positive was the intense story that I thoroughly enjoyed. The negatives were just the typical bugs and glitches and the un-optimisation of the game. The game wasn't outstanding or great by all means but I think it was a good game. It was a fun story to engage in and for me being a fan of Tom Clancy, it was a solid addition in the series. For $17.99, I can provide a moderate recommendation to purchase the game, however I say purchase it if you have friends to play with as you can play all the modes with them. 7.5/10

reviewText:
I played the Splinter Cell series from the beginning, and this is almost categorically not Splinter Cell.

The narrative, I feel, is a failure, but it's a failure that began with the principle plot point in Double Agent (the apparent death of Sam's daughter, Sarah)—which Ubisoft was understandably obligated to resolve in Conviction. While I can say I mostly enjoyed DA, Sam himself started to become too wrapped up in the story. What made the first three games so eerie and interesting is that there were functionally two narratives: there was the geo-political narrative unfolding throughout each game, that we, as Sam, watched silently from the shadows, almost literally like a ghost, in which we were observers and not actors; and then there was the dark narrative in which we crept through the darkness, drifting from scene to scene in the larger picture. These two narratives, in each of the first four games, would in the end combine, as Sam stepped out of the shadows, finally, to assassinate someone. It was a slow burn—and that was Splinter Cell as I knew it.

In Conviction, this distinction has disappeared. There is only one narrative, and it's focused on Sam. Creeping in the shadows is only the precursor to the inevitable high-octane action that each sequence is designed around. You could play through Chaos Theory, the pinnacle of the Splinter Cell series, literally without being seen; this play style was not only accomodated; it was encouraged. But I guess casual gamers didn't have the patience or the interest to invest into another slow burn Splinter Cell.

I haven't played Blacklist, but prior to its release I would have pegged Conviction as the death of the series.

reviewText:
Great new gameplay mechanics are introduced but becomes too uncanny for a series that should focus mainly on stealth.
Balance is out of the picture (as expected from a Ubisoft game) with the Mark & Execution feature being too simple and easy to exploit. New features like interrogation segments also don't do much, apart from being something like inevitable, interactive cutscenes.
What's worst is how the game consantly throws numerous enemies at you, expecting a combat reaction that can be felt as the only obvious choice you're always left with.
What's that? You want to sneak past enemies? Forget it. That's almost impossible unless you go super hardcore and have the patience of a tortoise. There's no room for real stealth with the cramped level design and the act of going into a killing spree is forced in your face.

Overall, this is almost nothing like what a Splinter Cell should be. The new stealth system took me too long to get used to but it does and by the time you do, it's an upset to what this game has turned out to be. Most SC oldschool fans can agree on this.
This is a simply shame, a pathetic attempt at appeasing the casuals by Ubisoft.

reviewText:
Splinter Cell Conviction is a 3rd person action game released by Ubisoft in 2010. It is a sequel to Splinter Cell Double Agent, and continues the storyline of Sam Fisher and Third Echelon.

Splinter Cell Conviction sees you guiding Sam Fisher as he tries to discover what happened to his daughter, and fights the same agency that employed you in the previous Splinter Cell games. The gameplay is similar to the previous entries, with emphasis put on finding cover in the environment. To help you stick to the shadows, the game turns black and white while you are hidden. There are a variety of gadgets available to you that fans of the earlier games will recognize. The gunplay is satisfying, however I did not find myself using much but the pistol for most of the game. Although there are other weapons available, usually the best method was just to sneak up close and go for the headshot. I'm assuming that there were ways to sneak through many areas undetected, however my Sam Fisher is a genocidal maniac, so if any enemies managed to survive the game, it was purely by mistake.

The graphics, sound and voice acting are top notch, as is usually expected from Ubisoft. They catch some flak for bugs and Uplay, but they always seem to bring it in those areas. I didn't experience any bugs, however I did play the game close to 5 years after release, so I imagine they were all ironed out by then.

The storyline is standard Splinter Cell fare. It's been a little while since I played Double Agent, so I found myself at times getting confused as to who was who. The general gist of what was going on wasn't hard to comprehend though. The story took about 4-5 hours to go through, which is a little shorter than I expected, but was a fun ride while it lasted. Also, who knew that slamming heads into tables is the world's best interrogation technique? Sam Fisher knew.

Overall I'd recommend Splinter Cell Conviction, even this long after release. It's a short, focused thriller that is enjoyable for the 4-5 hours that it takes. I didn't try the multiplayer because I have to assume it's dead by now, but the single player is worth the price.

Grade: B+

reviewText:
i have played splinter cell 3, 4, this one and blacklist. of those 4, i think blacklist gets the most things right. from that perspective, this game is still great, an easy 8 or 9 out of 10, but stealth is often optional and rather not encouraged in most of the normal campaign. as an action game it succeeds though, and stealth mechanics are in place if you choose to use them.
as far as weapons go, there are many more firearm choices than the previous games, all with 3 permanent upgrades you may purchase and apply. you can unlock an extra weapon with uplay points, as well as extra uniforms and a game mode that does put stealth at the fore. there is also a mode called 'deniable ops', which rewards stealth by not alerting backup forces, and the unlockable and upgradeable uniforms come into play in this (and other) modes.
the issue i do have with this game, which keeps it from being a solid 9 or 10 in my opinion, is the mechanic they use to show you when you are hidden/not hidden. everything turns black and white when you are hidden, in a sense penalizing you for remaining in the shadows. i spent a larger portion of the time playing in black and white or a close variant (goggle vision) than i wanted to, and felt this was a bad development choice for the game.
technically speaking, the game is much more stable than the also awesome 'double agent', which has many issues on the pc. i cant really say i noticed any technical problems running this game, aside from the fact it didnt work in 3d without using a less perfect mode (in tridef 3d) called 'power 3d'. i have to use power 3d with blacklist too, so i dont dock any points for this of course. true 3d is a bit better though, if anyone does care, but still looks great in power 3d. these things are not really the fault of the game, at any rate.
overall, i highly recommend getting the splinter cell elite echelon edition when it is on sale, as 3 of the 4 games in the pack still hold up today even as far as graphics and game mechanics go. this is one of them. the first is just too dated to work 100% optimally so i havent played it, though im sure it's an outstanding game in its own right.
one other thing i would like to mention about this game: though the cover/hide system that is perfected in blacklist makes an appearance here, the action oriented direction is apparent with the fact that you must constantly hold a trigger button in order to remain in cover, vs in blacklist where you remain in cover til you actively leave it. i prefer the more laid back pace of most of blacklist, but i plan to spend more hours playing conviction yet. it is a success, despite those couple of flaws.

reviewText:
'Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell:Conviction' turned out to be a fairly underwhelming experience to be honest.

The gameplay was simplistic and largely featureless. Picking up bodies is supposed to be a standard in stealth games which Conviction lacked, sadly. Regenerative health was done right as it took only a few shots for Sam to die. The gadgets were decent but I was left hoping they were more effective. Mark and Execute was a fun feature. It made things easy but I also found lots of utility for it. But all in all, the gameplay lacked variety.

The stealth segments were great and usually very tough. There was no option to distract guards without being detected so the only course left was to kill or sneak around them. It made stealth a lot more challenging this way. The absence of air vents was a welcome subtraction from a game belonging to the stealth genre.

AI was buggy. Enemies would either behave very intelligently or play entirely dumb. At times, even those Sonar goggle ninjas were unable to pinpoint my position. Enemy AI took a lot away from the overall experience.

Mission structures were decent. Level design was great and the settings very picturesque but the missions, themselves, were fairly linear. The plot was made to appear complex but there was very little underneath the surface actually.
The presentation was excellent! The way objectives would get projected on the walls........ very cool stuff.

I wish this game was more feature-rich and had a better variety of gameplay elements. Conviction had almost everything in its favour but Ubisoft blew it. This game could've been so much more......

Disappointing.

The earlier Splinter Cell games placed the emphasis on stealth. You hid in shadows, picked locks, and tried to finish a level without being detected. You tapped into security cameras, or planted your own, to learn combinations and secrets so you could advance sneakily through a level. There was an immense thrill to being a master covert spy.

So what has happened to the franchise? This game still promises stealth - you can sneak, hide, duck - but it's much easier to go in guns-blazing and shoot everybody. There are certain levels where mass-murder is the *only* option. Where is the brooding yet honourable Sam Fisher that everybody used to love? This Sam Fisher is a serial-killer scumbag. This feels like yet another generic-shooter with shadows tacked on so they can claim it's a Splinter Cell game.

The graphics are good - not standout, but generically average - and the sound is fine. Controls are competently designed. But the level designs are hopeless. Every level felt like a chore. The interrogation scenes are gratuitous violence of zero consequence.

I get the feeling that the publisher forced the studio to simplify the game, to appeal to a wider audience. But this game has been dumbed down into nothingness. Just like porridge, it might sustain you, but there's nothing enjoyable in the experience.

Surprisingly good.  Great even.  As a longtime fan of the Splinter Cell series, I was definitely wary going into this one.  From the previews and videos I'd seen, I expected something completely out of the spirit of Splinter Cell.  My expectations were pretty accurate, but surprisingly the game departed from the series in an interesting and satisfying way.  The Mark and Execute feature in particular is a great twist on the series' traditional slow-paced, tactical gameplay.  In the old games, you'd stalk guards until they were isolated and take them out one by one, silently (or sneak past them).  But with this new ability, the developers have boiled down that old method to one which is much less tedious but still gets the same point across.  Now you stalk down and silently kill one guard, then strategically position yourself and take out the rest with one fell swoop.  It combines the tense sneaking of the old game and adds a whole new layer of tactics to it.  Good show Ubisoft.

Not as mediocre as I thought it would be - it's ok.
Yes, there is a lot of bland cover based shooting and not enough sneaking, but it did not bother me too much. The single-player story is like a typical action movie - sweeping soundtrack, big scripted set pieces, fancy cinematics, implausible but gripping plot, and a bit too short. It was a bit confusing and difficult to follow, but that's no big deal.

Gameplay is solid but a bit formulaic, with tight linear levels lacking multiple approaches, and dumb AI that would do well to eat more carrots (they can't see in the dark). The stealth mechanics based around shadows and “last known position” work fairly well, but are a bit too arcade for my tastes. Multiplayer matchmaking is dead, which is sad as co-op missions seem like fun.

As for those who keep saying this is much worse than the old games like Chaos theory, I slightly disagree, its not significantly better or worse. I am ok with the slightly more streamlined and faster paced direction they have taken, the difference is not as big as many make it out to be.
